title: Renesas/Dialog: cashing in the chips
text:
Being an Apple supplier is both a blessing and a curse. Anglo-German Dialog Semiconductor has striven to become less reliant on the smartphone maker by diversification. A takeover has long looked like the logical alternative. On Monday, Japan's Renesas Electronics announced a €4.9bn cash bid, pushing up Dialog's shares by 16 per cent to €65 — just below the €67.50-a-share offer.

Renesas will benefit from Dialog's design expertise. It is one of the biggest chip suppliers to the automotive sector, which is becoming more demanding. But its balance sheet was already stretched. The deal will be funded by issuing new shares. Renesas's share price fell by nearly 4 per cent.

Still, the price looks reasonable when held up against comparable deals. The enterprise value applied to Dialog is 3.8 times 2022 sales — a similar multiple to that paid by Infineon Technologies when it bought its US rival Cypress in 2019.

Renesas is counting on the deal leading to additional revenue growth. Investors are often sceptical of cross-selling claims, though it is the case that semiconductor customers increasingly prefer to buy multiple components from the same vendor.

The Japanese company has also pencilled in $125m per year of cost savings. Taxed and capitalised that would cover slightly less than half the premium above Dialog's average share price over the past three months. Shares have outperformed over that period, but this is owing to a mix of takeover speculation and strong demand from its biggest customer.

Cross-border deals in the semiconductor industry are sensitive. Renesas — founded in 2003 from three struggling chipmakers — knows that more than most. In 2012, a government-backed fund thwarted an attempt by rival US fund KKR to buy a majority stake in it.

But Dialog — US-founded, UK-domiciled and Frankfurt-traded — is no national champion. Dialog would add less than 5 percentage points to Renesas's share of any of its markets, estimates UBS. The deal looks likely to go ahead, as part of a wider consolidation in the semiconductor industry.
